title: Ticket #7489: HTCondor can't annex Spot
description:
On January 24, 2020, we received a user report that condor_annex could no longer use Spot instances. After reproducing the initial user report, and having made no changes to the code, we contacted the Head of AWS Research to see what was going on. He put us in contact with the Principal Developer Advocate for EC2 Spot, who was quickly able to tell us: 

The dev team tracked things down. A change was rolled out that flipped the
parameters to UpperCamelCase (i.e. "tagSpecificationSet" to
"TagSpecificationSet", "groupSet" to "GroupSet", "blockDeviceMapping" to
"BlockDeviceMapping").

We made the obvious changes to the code, confirmed that they solved the problem, and had pre-releases ready for distribution the next day.
remarks:
original description:
Daniel Corbett wrote on 2020 January 24 to say that he was getting the following error when trying to use condor_annex with Spot Fleet: 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>\n
<Response>
<Errors><Error>UnknownParameter
<Message>The parameter groupSet is not recognized</Message>
</Error></Errors>
<RequestID>6e371b3b-bdd9-4df6-a0e1-a9c4b8d57d1e</RequestID>
</Response>

The problem was trivial to reproduce on our resources, but did not happen as a result of any code changes that we made or configuration changes made by Daniel.

2020-Feb-06 15:39:58 by tlmiller:
Because the protocol change was only from a lower to an upper case letter, it may be possible to fix older binaries by editing the string constants in place. The following pair of commands did the trick on a binary built from the top of the 8.9.5 release branch (assuming ec2_gahp is in your PATH): 

perl -p -i -e 's/groupSet\./GroupSet./' `which ec2_gahp`
perl -p -i -e 's/tagSpecificationSet\.1\./TagSpecificationSet.1./' `which ec2_gahp`

These commands (or the equivalent invocations of sed, if you don't have perl installed) may work on other version of the ec2_gahp as well; it's not particularly likely that the bytes of those two strings collide with any binary code. However, you should certainly make a back-up copy of the ec2_gahp first. You can check to make sure that only two bytes were change by running hexdump on the ec2_gahp before and after and comparing them: 

cp `which ec2_gahp` ec2_gahp.backup
hexdump `which ec2_gahp` > unmodified.dump
perl -p -i -e 's/groupSet\./GroupSet./' `which ec2_gahp`
perl -p -i -e 's/tagSpecificationSet\.1\./TagSpecificationSet.1./' `which ec2_gahp`
hexdump `which ec2_gahp` > modified.dump
diff -u unmodified.dump modified.dump

The diff should show only two changed lines.
